text: LEDs will give an amazing look to any
project
remember the Deaf Punk helmet with
addressable LEDs but now I have another
project full of colors I've made a
Tetris table with some cool features the
board is quite big with a total of 128
RGB LEDs and the display configuration
of 8 by 16 I've used the base code from
original server and added a few extra
parts I've placed two seven segment
displays in order to show the score and
the top score the top score will be
saved to the EEPROM memory of the
Arduino so it will stay there even if
you par off the game I've also placed a
pause option so you could stop the game
and continue later but one of the best
improvement will be the sound option
I've used again the df' player with some
mp3 files on an SD card and play the
tetris team sound
it will also play some tones when you
pass the game also when you lose when
you restart the game and we also have a
short bit each time that you complete
the line you could also now reset the
game with a push button when you get the
countdown to move the pieces you could
use the joystick or some push buttons
I've made the case with plywood and some
acrylic parts and still need some
details in order to improve the look but
I think is quite good for now I'll maybe
paint it with varnish and add some
better labels as well so if you want to
build this cool project check the part
list the schematic and the code below
this video and let's see what we need
and the steps to build this playing this
is quite fun but building it is even
better and you could also learn a few
new things make sure that you subscribe
and hit a notification bell as well
thanks to all my Peters for supporting
my channel so guys let's get started the

thanks to all users feedback they are
improving their services every day even
this is your first time ordering PCBs is
very easy and all you have to do is to
upload the Gerber files to June CPC
b.com select the settings that you want
and you could get 5 PCBs of any color
for only $2 what's up my friends welcome
back let's take a look at the finished
tetris table and then see how to build
it it can be powered from the main
outlet because we have a small power
supply inside for 5 volts so press the
on button and it will start the game and
the tetris theme song will play as well
so now you can use the joystick to move
the pieces left and right to accelerate
downwards or rotate the piece press the
pause button and the game will stop till
you press that button again at the same
time the P letter will appear on the LED
matrix and you'll also hear the past
sound each time that you finish a line
you'll hear a very short bit from the
buzzer and ten more points will be added
to the 7-segment display on the right
display we have the top score and this
will be saved to the EEPROM memory of
the Arduino so it will be saved even if
you unpack the game in this way multiple
players could try to beat your score if
you want you could use the push buttons
to do the same as with the joysticks I
will probably use these buttons in the
future for a second game so it's good to
have these buttons as well on the other
side we have the USB input of the
arduino and another toggle switch you
could use the switch to enable or
disable the music if we take a look
inside we can see the power supply for 5
volts they are doing Omega that will run
the code the DF player for the mp3
sounds together with a small speaker and
the display a joystick and the buttons
on the top plate below the acrylic part
we have the matrix of 128 RGB
addressable LEDs and that means we could
control the brightness and the color of
each LED using just a single serial
cable and that makes this project a lot
easier than using one cable for each LED
or a matrix driver I've already played a
few games and I can say it is really fun
okay so playing this is very fun but I
like building it even more so let's see
what we need to make this remember to
check the part list the schematic and
the code below on return oops calm and
also under the website Electra moves
that I oh okay guys so we start with a
piece of plywood of five millimeters
thickness I'm using the ws2812 LED strip
and the first thing that I do is to
measure the distance between the LEDs in
this case is 33 millimeters you have
another type of LED strip with more LEDs
and these are a lot closer one to each
other but I recommended to use the one
with fewer LEDs I mark on the plywood a
grid of eight lines for the columns and
sixteen lines for the rows and separated
33 millimeters one for the other
once I have to 128 squares it's time to
cut the plywood I'm using a cutter to do
that so once I cut apart I use in
sending paper to smooth the edges pass
the sending paper all over the sides
okay so now we have the main pie with
base you can check the final dimensions
of this board below this video in the
same way I cut four more parts for the
sides this will be as long as the board
but with a weight of five centimeters
you have to cut two long pieces for the
sides and two more for the top and
bottom parts we have to leave a small
part below the LED matrix as well since
we will place the electronics here later
now it's time to add the LEDs now take
the strip and divide it into smaller
strips of eight LEDs each you will need
16 strips of eight LEDs we have to place
one strip on each row like this make
sure that the strips are good size and
fit okay on the plywood but before we
glue them in place we have to cut a
small part of the board so we could
press the wires on the other side I mark
the position of the strip more or less
and then I cut a small part from the
plywood now you should have 16 holes on
each side like this
now when I place the LED strip it will
be able to pass on the other side so
it's time to glue the strips if you take
a look from close you will see that the
strip has a small error on it so this
will show the direction of the serial
data make sure that you play the strip
like this the first line with the arrow
to the left the second to the right the
third to the left and so on this will be
placed in the shape of an S and the
first led will be here and the last one
here each line of LEDs will have some
glue on the backside so you don't need
any other kind of glue okay so now that
we have the LEDs in place we can solder
wires between the strips we need 5 volts
ground and the data for each strip to
make the connections and since you guys
always ask me about the team wire that
I'm using well this is the wire that I
have in all my projects I will place an
ebay link below if you want for around
eight dollars you can get two hundred
meters of this 30 gauge wire of
different colors it's very easy to use
and very thin and for small signal is
perfect okay so we have to solder a red
one black and one green wire for 5 volts
for ground and data from each line as in
the schematic each two strips now all
the strip's are connected and to the
first one I will solder the wires that
will later go to the Arduino and the
power supply so with this the main board
is ready now have to make the squares
that would affect the light and give it
a better look but to do that I want to
apply wood but instead I will use this
kind of foam that is used for RC plane
modeling it's very easy to cut and it is
white and that will reflect the light
even better we need to cut 16 small
strips and 7 long ones and each of 4
centimetres width because we need to
subtract the thickness of the bottom
plywood and the acrylic on the top from
those 5 centimeters before I mark the
lines for all the strips and I cut 16
small ones and 7 long strips cutting
this foam is very easy just use a cutter
once again ok so now here comes the long
and boring part of this project in order
to join the long strips with the short
ones and great
greed we need to cut a small part from
each one so 7 holes in the short strip
and 15 holes in the long ones so from
this we get to this so after more than
one hour I have all the parts so it's
time to place the grid over the LEDs
place the long ones and on top of that
you can place the short ones once you
complete the grid you have to make sure
that each line of foam is on top of the
lines that we have on the bottom plywood
so once wholly centered and in the right
place you can use just a little bit of
hot glue and fix the foam grid in place
we need this grid to create a square
shape of the light from the LEDs because
otherwise you will have just a spot
light and the colors from one LED will
blend with the cars from the LEDs around
and that won't look good
this grid with the acrylic on top will
look a lot better once I had the foam
grid for the squares I can place the
other pieces of plywood all around and
create some sort of case for that I used
some hot glue for now and later I'll let
some wood glue as well so the case is
ready now we need the white acrylic part
that will cover the LEDs I have this
huge acrylic board from what oldrover
that I thrown away but I kept the

on the bottom part of the case I can
place the rest of the electronics make
sure that the acrylic part will fit okay
inside of the case and once the project
is ready we'll also do this in place now
I decide where I can place the power
supply and the Arduino and cut some
holes for that as well for the main end
the USB cable and speaking of
electronics let's see what we need you
will need the Arduino mega because the
uno has low memory and it is not enough
for this project for the soup I will use
the small supply of 5 volts from the
mains input of 230 volts you will need
of course the vs 28 12 addressable LED
strip and you also need one module of
seven segment display with the max
driver then you will need a simple
joystick and some momentary push buttons
d/f player to play the mp3 sounds and an
SD card and maybe an audio amplifier but
I finally decided to connect the speaker
directly to the DF player because it was
powerful enough you also need an owner
and maybe an audio all the connections I
first to the hole and place the enough
switch and I solder some wires between
this button and the power supply on the
other side I place the amplifier
potentiometer but hour later change this
with a toggle switch to enable or
disable the sound and that's it I solder
some wires from the DF player just as in
the schematic
I also soldered the power and the data
cables for the 7-segment display I now
check where to place each component
inside of the case once again I've
decided to remove the amplifier and net
a toggle switch instead of that inside
this case we'll have the Arduino the
speaker the DF player and the supply and
on the top part will have the 7-segment
display and the push buttons on one side
and the joystick on the other side I put
everything in place using hot glue or
screws and make the connections using
wires remember to download the mp3 files

DF player so now everything is connected
the supply will give 5 volts to dispatch
and from here we'll supply all the
modules the buttons are connected to the
Arduino the 7-segment display as well
and of course remember to connect the
data pin from the LED strip to the
Arduino as well when you're ready check
the connections once again then plug the
USB and upload the code from below now
unplug the USB cable connect the main
plug and power on the game so this
project is a success the game will start
and you will hear the music and be able
to play the game I recommend you to make
some tests before you glue everything
inside of the case because once the
strip is glued it will be very difficult
to make changes without breaking
something so close the case and the game
board is ready as an extra you can add
some labels for the start and pause
buttons you can paint the case and make

is the final look of my Arduino
